title: Preliminary Calculations of the Main Gephyrotron and its Power Supply
The Supply Of Canadian Hydrocarbons To The United States
container-title: SPE California Regional Meeting
items.abstract:
<jats:p>Haun, David D., Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Calgary, Canada</jats:p>
               <jats:p>This paper was prepared for the 44th Annual California Regional Meeting of the Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, to be held in San Francisco, California, April 4–5, 1974. Permission to copy is restricted to an abstract of not more than 300 words. Illustrations may not be copied. The abstract should contain conspicuous acknowledgement of where and by whom the paper is presented. Publication elsewhere after publication in the JOURNAL OF PETROLEUM TECHNOLOGY or the SOCIETY OF publication in the JOURNAL OF PETROLEUM TECHNOLOGY or the SOCIETY OF PETROLEUM ENGINEERS JOURNAL is usually granted upon request to the Editor PETROLEUM ENGINEERS JOURNAL is usually granted upon request to the Editor of the appropriate journal provided agreement to give proper credit is made.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Discussion of this paper is invited. Three copies of any discussion should be sent to the Society of Petroleum Engineers office. Such discussion may be presented at the above meeting and, with the paper, may be considered for publication in one of the two SPE magazines.</jats:p>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>In 1973 the Canadian oil industry produced 2.0 million barrels per day of crude oil which in world terms makes Canada a relatively small producer. The country ranked 9th in terms of producer. The country ranked 9th in terms of 1972 crude oil production with 3.4% of the total world rate and 15th in terms of remaining reserves with 1.5% of the world total of 560 billion barrels. Exports to the United States in 1973 averaged 1,127 thousand barrels per day of crude oil and pentanes plus, which accounted only for 6.5% of the total U.S. demand for all hydrocarbons (or 35% of U.S. crude oil imports), but it did amount to 58% of Canada's total production. Production of conventional crude production. Production of conventional crude from the presently producing area, the western Canadian Sedimentary Basin, is expected to continue at the present level for only a few years and then show a sharp decline. Intensive development of synthetic oil from tar sands and heavy oil areas could to some extent mitigate this decline, but the availability of frontier oil in the 1980's will be necessary to recover to the present supply situation. As a result of present supply situation. As a result of increased demand in present Canadian market areas for Western crude and the additional demand resulting from the construction of the Montreal Pipeline, the volume of exports to the U.S. will drop sharply by the end of this decade. The only alternatives to a complete cessation of crude oil exports by the early 1980's would be earlier movement of Mackenzie Delta oil to west-Coast markets through the Alyeska Pipe line or a smaller supply to Montreal than now planned. These alternatives will, however, only reduce the rate of decline in exports to the U.S.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>In 1973 the Canadian oil industry produced 2.0 million barrels per day of crude oil and pentanes plus and 6.1 billion cubic feet per pentanes plus and 6.1 billion cubic feet per day of natural gas. Canada rated 9th in terms of 1972 crude oil production with 3.4% of the total world rate and 15th in terms of remaining reserves with 1.5% of the world total of 560 billion barrels.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>During the year 1973 the Canadian industry exported to the United States an average of 1,127,000 barrels per day of crude oil and pentanes plus and 2,821 MMCF/Day of natural pentanes plus and 2,821 MMCF/Day of natural gas. While the levels represented only a small proportion of total United States demand (6.5% proportion of total United States demand (6.5% of the demand for all hydrocarbon liquids, and 4.4% of natural gas consumption), they did account for high proportions of Canada's productive capacity, 58% of oil producibility productive capacity, 58% of oil producibility and 46% of pipeline gas volumes.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

title: Supply Problems of Small Unit Grocers:
container-title: International Journal of Physical Distribution
items.abstract: <jats:p>This paper examines the way small unit retailers in Nottingham Metropolitan area use the two major channels of distribution available to them. It suggests that these two forms of wholesaling are, to some extent, counter productive and concludes that the problems of supply require detailed examination if the future of the independent retailer in Britain is to be assured.</jats:p>

title: Economic damages from residential use of mineralized water supply
container-title: Water Resources Research
items.abstract: <jats:p>Household appliances and personal items in contact with water supplied municipally or from private sources are subject to physical damages from chemical and other constituents of the water. This study translates these damages into economic losses for a typical household. Then it aggregates these losses at the national and individual state levels. To do so required several stages of analysis. First, the types of physical damages expected and the associated water quality determinants were identified, and the physical effects were then translated into economic losses. Second, damage functions were formulated to predict likely impacts of water quality changes on each household unit affected. Third, a computer program based on these functions was designed to estimate total damages per typical household and to aggregate them over selected regions. Finally, the program was applied to state‐by‐state data describing water supply sources and socioeconomic parameters. Total annual damages to U.S. residents in 1970 were estimated to be in the range $0.65–$3.45 billion, the mean being $1.75 billion. The mean translates to $8.60 per person annually. States having the highest total damages were California ($230 million) and Illinois ($164 million). On a per capita basis, Arizona ($22.53) and New Mexico ($18.58) ranked highest, whereas South Carolina ($1.15) and Oregon ($1.73) were at the other end of the spectrum. When per capita damages were compared by source of water supply, private wells were highest at an average of $12.34, treated groundwater was next at $11.20, and treated surface water was last at only $5.83.</jats:p>

title: A systems approach to assessment of rural water supply program effectiveness
container-title: Water Resources Research
items.abstract: <jats:p>Systems analysis was used to improve the methodology of impact evaluation by determining the role of resource constraints and complementary inputs in the development of the rural water supply program in Thailand. An impact evaluation was undertaken to analyze the effectiveness of the National Potable Water Project and to provide feedback to the government for improving the administrative, technical, and operational aspects of the program. Objectives of the evaluation were to provide guidelines for design, construction, finance, and administration of the potable water projects; operational guidance for management; information for training plant operators; and feedback on villager attitudes, water habits, water use, and village development. The methodology developed measured the social, economic, and public health implications of the water projects toward achieving rural community development. Data are being collected from some 165 village projects throughout northeast Thailand.</jats:p>

title: An inexpensive voltage-stabilized power supply for strain-gauge applications
container-title: Journal of Strain Analysis
items.abstract: <jats:p> The development of a simple, inexpensive power supply for strain-gauge applications, with a long-term voltage stability of better than 1 part in 1000, is described. </jats:p>

title: Effects of Colorado River water quality and supply on irrigated agriculture
container-title: Water Resources Research
items.abstract: <jats:p>A production function relating irrigated crop yield to the quality and supply of irrigation water is developed. It was found that the adverse effects of saline irrigation water can be offset by application of additional water over and above that required for plant transpiration. Results indicate that a degradation of the water supply in the Colorado River at Imperial Dam from the existing level of electroconductivity of 1.50 mmho to the projected level for the year 2000 of 2.0 mmho would cause a decline in the return to land and water of about 14% for farmers in the Imperial Valley of California. Because of the relatively elastic demand for irrigation water at the current price, any attempt to ration water through a market price mechanism would have no effect, unless water rates were about double their current levels.</jats:p>

title: Optimal timing and sizing of a conjunctive urban water supply and waste water system with nonlinear programing
container-title: Water Resources Research
items.abstract: <jats:p>A mathematical model of a conjunctively operated urban water supply and waste water system is formulated and applied to the city of Los Angeles. The objectives are (1) to minimize the cost of supplying water from several sources, including the provision for recycling reclaimed water, and (2) to determine the capacity expansion schedule of the water and waste water treatment processes. The water sources vary in quality, quantity, and cost. Constraints on water quality constituents as well as on quantity are included. The model formulated consists of the minimization of a concave objective function subject to linear constraints. A multilevel solution technique is developed to determine the minimum cost alternative for a selected planning horizon. The mathematical model is flexible in that it can be expanded to include additional water quality constituents, advanced waste water treatment processes, and variations in water quality standards.</jats:p>

title: Effect of Potassium Supply on the Transport of Photosynthates to the Fruits of Tomatoes (Lycopersicon esculentum)
container-title: Physiologia Plantarum
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In experiments with intact tomato plants the effect of potassium on the translocation of photosynthates was studied. Four series of plants were grown in nutrient solutions with two different potassium levels (K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> treatments). When the fruits of the first truss had developed the plants were treated with labelled CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> for 2 h in a glove box. The plants were then divided in roots, stems, fruits and leaves, which were prepared for chemical analysis.</jats:p><jats:p>In all experimental series the plants with the higher K supply grew better and therefore assimilated higher amounts of labelled CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (cpm/plant). The assimilation rates per g fresh material, however, were not increased in each experimental set by the K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> treatment. The absolute quantities of labelled photosynthates transported from leaves and stems to the fruits were also greater in the plant with the higher potassium supply. In all experimental series the proportion of labelled material found in the fruits was higher in the plants of the K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> treatment (total label of the plant=100%) than in the plants of the K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> treatment. This beneficial effect of potassium was also observed in cases, where potassium had not affected the CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> assimilation rate. Expressing the distribution of labelled material in relative terms (percentage proportions) means that the effect of CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> assimilation on the transport of photosynthates was excluded to a high extent. The higher percentage proportions of labelled material found in fruits and roots of the K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> as compared to the K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> treatment is, therefore, predominantly dependent on a specific effect of potassium on the translocation of assimilates.</jats:p><jats:p>The labelled material found in the soluble fraction of the stems consisted of about 90% sugars, nearly half of which was sucrose, the rest being mainly glucose and fructose. This finding suggests that sucrose is the most important transport form of carbohydrates in tomatoes.</jats:p>
